pre-requisites: Basic understanding of Python programming, linear algebra, and probability theory. Prior knowledge of machine learning and healthcare is helpful but not required.
description: Deep Learning for Healthcare (DLH301) is an interdisciplinary course designed to equip students with advanced knowledge and practical skills in deep learning techniques specifically tailored for healthcare applications. This course focuses on understanding and implementing state-of-the-art deep learning models to address complex healthcare challenges, such as disease diagnosis, treatment planning, medical imaging, genomics, and personalized medicine.

material.topic: Introduction to Deep Learning and Healthcare
reading: Deep Learning by Ian Goodfellow, Yoshua Bengio, and Aaron Courville
Deep Medicine: How Artificial Intelligence Can Make Healthcare Human Again by Eric Topol

material.topic: Neural Networks and Convolutional Neural Networks
reading: Deep Learning for Computer Vision by Adrian Rosebrock
Convolutional Neural Networks in Visual Computing: A Concise Guide by Ragav Venkatesan and Baoxin Li

material.topic: Recurrent Neural Networks and Long Short-Term Memory Networks
reading: Understanding LSTM Networks by Christopher Olah
Supervised Sequence Labelling with Recurrent Neural Networks by Alex Graves
Deep Learning for Medical Image Analysis by S. Kevin Zhou, Hayit Greenspan, and Dinggang Shen
Handbook of Medical Image Computing and Computer Assisted Intervention by S. Kevin Zhou, Daniel Rueckert, and Gabor Fichtinger

material.topic: Electronic Health Records and Predictive Analytics
reading: Secondary Analysis of Electronic Health Records by MIT Critical Data
Predictive Analytics in Healthcare: Concepts, Models, and Methods by Ken Yale
Deep Learning for the Life Sciences: Applying Deep Learning to Genomics, Microscopy, Drug Discovery, and More by Bharath Ramsundar, Peter Eastman, Patrick Walters, and Vijay Pande
Personalized Medicine: Empowered Patients in the 21st Century? by Barbara Prainsack
The Ethics of AI and Big Data in Healthcare by Laura Cabrera, and Elizabeth F. Hutton
Healthcare Data Privacy and Security: Regulatory Compliance and Data Security in the Age of Electronic Health Records by Bernard Peter Robichau
No specific readings, review previous weeks' materials and focus on project presentations

pre-requisites: Basic understanding of Python programming, algorithms, and data structures.
description: Python for Backend Engineering (PBE201) is an in-depth course designed to provide students with the essential knowledge and practical skills required to build scalable, robust, and maintainable backend systems using Python. This course covers a wide range of topics, including web frameworks, databases, RESTful APIs, caching, and performance optimization. Students will gain hands-on experience by working on real-world projects and implementing best practices in backend engineering.

material.topic: Introduction to Backend Engineering and Python
reading: Python Crash Course by Eric Matthes
Fluent Python: Clear, Concise, and Effective Programming by Luciano Ramalho
Django for Beginners: Build Websites with Python and Django by William S. Vincent
Two Scoops of Django: Best Practices for the Django Web Framework by Daniel Roy Greenfeld and Audrey Roy Greenfeld
SQL: The Complete Reference by James R. Groff, Paul N. Weinberg, and Andrew J. Oppel
Seven Databases in Seven Weeks: A Guide to Modern Databases and the NoSQL Movement by Luc Perkins, Eric Redmond, and Jim Wilson
RESTful Web APIs by Leonard Richardson and Mike Amundsen
API Design Patterns: The Importance of API Design Standards for Business-to-Business by Casey Reas and Ben Fry
High Performance Django by Peter Baumgartner and Yann Malet
Web Scalability for Startup Engineers by Artur Ejsmont
Asynchronous Python Web Apps with WebSockets & gevent by Andrew Godwin
Python Parallel Programming Cookbook by Giancarlo Zaccone
Building Microservices: Designing Fine-Grained Systems by Sam Newman
Docker: Up & Running: Shipping Reliable Containers in Production by Sean P. Kane and Karl Matthias
Clean Code: A Handbook of Agile Software Craftsmanship by Robert C. Martin
You Don't Know JS (book series) by Kyle Simpson

pre-requisites: Intermediate understanding of Python programming, linear algebra, and probability theory. Prior knowledge of machine learning is required.
description: Artificial Intelligence in Production (AIP301) is a course designed to equip students with the knowledge and skills required to deploy machine learning models in production environments. This course covers a wide range of topics, including model deployment, scaling, monitoring, and continuous integration and delivery. Students will also gain experience in cloud infrastructure and containerization technologies to deploy and manage AI-based systems in production.

material.topic: Continuous Integration and Delivery for ML
reading: Continuous Delivery: Reliable Software Releases through Build, Test, and Deployment Automation by Jez Humble and David Farley
Building Machine Learning Powered Applications: Going from Idea to Product by Emmanuel Ameisen

material.topic: Monitoring and Debugging ML Models in Production
reading: Practical Monitoring: Effective

material.topic: Cloud Infrastructure and Containerization for AI
reading: Kubernetes: Up and Running: Dive into the Future of Infrastructure by Brendan Burns, Joe Beda, and Kelsey Hightower
Cloud Native Infrastructure: Patterns for Scalable Infrastructure and Applications in a Dynamic Environment by Justin Garrison and Kris Nova

material.topic: Ethical and Legal Issues in AI Deployment
reading: The Big Nine: How the Tech Titans and Their Thinking Machines Could Warp Humanity by Amy Webb
Robot Rights by David J. Gunkel
Building Machine Learning Powered Applications: Going from Idea to Product by Emmanuel Ameisen
